Exit / exodus / portability patterns\n\n- **Layer‑2 exit formats.** Statechannels’ “Standard Exit Format for L2s built on EVM chains” defines a generic data structure and Solidity utilities for exiting rollups and channels, aiming at interoperable payouts when moving assets back to L1. This is asset‑exit, not “social/reputation” exit, but it is a true exit **format** that could be a conceptual cousin for your receipt semantics. [github](https://github.com/statechannels/exit-format)\n- **DAO ragequit as exit primitive.** Moloch‑style ragequit implements a minority‑protection exit: a member can withdraw their proportional share of treasury assets before a contentious decision executes, surrendering governance rights. Mechanism Institute’s write‑up explicitly frames ragequit as an “exit mechanism” with economic finality and minority safeguards. [moloch.daohaus](https://moloch.daohaus.fun/features/ragequit)\n- **Broader “exit + interoperability” ecosystem.** Some essays survey open social/web protocols (AT Protocol, Fediverse, etc.) as early proof that exit and interoperability “exist today” through DID‑backed identities and portable social graphs. These mostly stop at portability of accounts and feeds, with little in the way of explicit “dispute‑aware” exit rituals. [platformocracy](https://www.platformocracy.com/p/exit-and-interoperability-exist-today-if-you-know-where-to-look)\n\nWithin your taxonomy, these are **exit‑enablement for assets and memberships**, but almost none model exit as a structured, evidence‑rich ritual beyond “update balances and permissions.”\n\n## 2. Identity, VCs, and portable reputation\n\n- **Portable reputation reference app (Affinidi).** Affinidi’s “Portable reputation” reference app shows a DID/VC‑based pattern where verifiable credentials encode a user’s reputation (e.g., reviews, scores) that can be presented across contexts. It’s squarely in the identity + reputation layer: what’s portable is a VC; the issuer is typically a platform or business; there’s no explicit exit ritual, just issuance and presentation. [github](https://github.com/affinidi/reference-app-portable-rep)\n- **Verifiable credential movement for business reputation.** Business‑oriented articles describe “portable reputation” as VCs businesses can use to prove trustworthiness across platforms (ratings, certifications, KYC, etc.). Again, the focus is on *having* a credential, not on how you leave a platform safely. [jasminedirectory](https://www.jasminedirectory.com/blog/the-verifiable-credential-movement-portable-reputation-for-businesses/)\n- **Cheqd and verifiable AI / data.** cheqd’s work on “Verifiable AI” and data markets extends VCs to AI inputs/outputs and compliance attestations, emphasizing provenance and portability of claims. This is close to “trust plumbing” for exit receipts but doesn’t itself define exit workflows. [cheqd](https://cheqd.io/blog/verifiable-ai-by-cheqd/)\n\nIn your terms, these are **identity/reputation layers** and “attestation registry” examples: strong enablers but not competitors unless they start packaging specific “leave with receipts” flows.\n\n## 3. Recovery and account abstraction (adjacent, not exit)\n\n- **EIP‑7947 / AARI.** The Account Abstraction Recovery Interface defines a universal `recoverAccess(subject, provider, proof)` pattern for smart accounts, plus provider‑management functions, so users can restore access via multiple recovery providers rather than seed phrases. This is a very explicit recovery standard, but it addresses *continuity of control* rather than exit; it is in your “recovery layer” bucket. [ethereum-magicians](https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-7947-account-abstraction-recovery-interface-aari/24080)\n- **AA explainer stacks.** Guides from security and infra teams highlight account abstraction’s support for social and seedless recovery via guardians and multi‑sig setups. These are UX and safety improvements that make “not losing your account” easier; they don’t usually include migration or exit semantics. [certik](https://www.certik.com/resources/blog/what-is-account-abstraction)\n\nThese are important because they define how agents maintain continuity of custody and control; they’re **adjacent infrastructure** that your exit rituals would likely plug into, not direct competitors.\n\n## 4. Agent identity, lineage, and non‑human context\n\n- **Agent Identity URI and topology‑independent naming.** Recent work on an “Agent Identity URI Scheme” proposes agent://‑style identifiers and capability‑based discovery for multi‑agent systems, with an emphasis on topology‑independent naming and secure capability delegation. This creates a layer where the *same* agent can move across environments while retaining capabilities, which is a natural home for successor/continuity semantics. [web3.arxiv](https://web3.arxiv.org/abs/2601.14567)\n- **Context lineage for non‑human identities.** Newer research on “Context Lineage Assurance for Non‑Human Identities in Critical Multi‑Agent Systems” and related “chronicles” / forensic frameworks deals with maintaining verifiable lineage of agent actions and states over time. These systems care about provenance, tamper‑evident logs, and reconstructable context for safety and forensics. [arxiv](https://www.arxiv.org/abs/2509.18415)\n\nThese are very close to your Cluster C: **agent‑native lineage**. They don’t necessarily speak in “exit” language, but they provide the **lineage and continuity proofs** you’d want underneath an exit‑with‑receipts protocol.\n\n## 5. [jasminedirectory](https://www.jasminedirectory.com/blog/the-verifiable-credential-movement-portable-reputation-for-businesses/)\n  - Usually stop at “you can carry this credential,” not “here is how you ceremonially leave system X.”\n- **Recovery layer (adjacent):**\n  - Account abstraction recovery standards (EIP‑7947 AARI), guardian‑based recovery flows, smart‑account UX work. [zeeve](https://www.zeeve.io/blog/exploring-the-benefits-of-account-abstraction-in-rollups/)\n  - Critical for continuity and safety but not exit‑focused.\n- **Exit enablement (closest to competition):**\n  - L2 exit formats like statechannels/exit‑format: genuine exit formats for asset withdrawal, with interoperability benefits. [mechanism](https://www.mechanism.institute/library/rage-quit)\n  - “Exit \u0026 interoperability” essays and emerging “Exodus Protocols” framing that talk explicitly about preserving exit through portability and higher‑level exodus design for systems/communities. [developer.blockchaincommons](https://developer.blockchaincommons.com/assets/pdfs/2025-10-tabconf-bb.pdf)\n\nWhat is **still rare**:\n\n- Exit modeled as a **multi‑step ritual** with roles, state machine, and explicit semantics for:\n  - pre‑exit commitments and notice,\n  - generation of structured, portable receipts (VCs, logs, proofs),\n  - dispute‑aware evidence that can be checked by third parties without the origin platform online. [arxiv](https://arxiv.org/html/2504.12612v1)\n\nThat gap is basically your “Cellar Door” space: **exit as a first‑class, agent‑native ceremony** with portable, third‑party‑verifiable receipts, rather than just “we issue a credential” or “you can withdraw funds.”\n\nIf you want, next step could be: I construct a small markdown table of 10–15 concrete named projects/specs (Affinidi portable reputation app, cheqd verifiable AI, EIP‑7947, statechannels exit‑format, Moloch/DAO ragequit, one or two Exodus‑protocol patterns, one or two agent‑lineage specs) with the fields you listed (what’s portable, issuer, lineage, dispute‑aware, offline verification, custody, ZK).\n\n(Initial search)",

      "text": "Across the different “exit” contexts (L2 exits, cross‑chain, DAOs, identity/VC, agent systems), people implicitly assume a surprisingly rich set of data and guarantees for a general EXIT primitive. Below is the *maximal* union of what shows up as “needed” once you read between the lines; you can then pare it down.\n\n## 1. Core identity, role, and jurisdiction\n\nAny general EXIT primitive tends to assume:\n\n- **Stable identifiers for parties.**  \n  - Persistent identifiers for the exiting entity (account, DID, agent URI), counterparties, and the system being exited.  \n  - Optional representation of **roles** (member, validator, customer, controller, guardian).\n\n- **Authority / jurisdiction context.**  \n  - Which domain or “realm” the exit is from (L2 rollup X, DAO Y, platform Z, tenant A in system B).  \n  - Applicable policy set or governance regime: which ruleset or contract governs this exit instance.\n\nThese primitives let verifiers later answer: “Who left what, from where, and under which law/rules?”\n\n## 2. Current state and obligations snapshot\n\nMost serious exit/bridge/channel formats assume you capture a **snapshot of state** that exit is operating on:\n\n- **Balances and allocations.**  \n  - For asset exits: per‑asset balances, allocations to destinations, and total conserved value.  \n  - For social/org exits: current membership status, voting power, reputation score, or entitlements.\n\n- **Outstanding commitments.**  \n  - Pending obligations: open disputes, slashed stakes, queued proposals, unvested rewards, or locked periods.  \n  - Time‑ or height‑bound conditions (e.g., “you can only exit if you have not voted in proposal N after block B”).\n\n- **Version / fork context.**  \n  - Which version of the contract/protocol, and which chain or fork, this state comes from.  \n\nWithout an agreed “pre‑exit snapshot,” you can’t later argue about whether the exit was legitimate.\n\n## 3. Exit intent, parameters, and policy hooks\n\nAn EXIT primitive usually needs to encode *what kind of exit* and under what terms:\n\n- **Type of exit.**  \n  - Voluntary vs forced (ragequit/penalty, liquidation, slashing).  \n  - Partial vs full (some assets/rights retained; some moved).  \n  - Immediate vs scheduled (exit effective at time T or after period Δ).\n\n- **Scope.**  \n  - Which assets, rights, or relationships are being terminated or ported (funds, voting power, access rights, data, reputation).  \n  - Whether this is a pure withdrawal, a migration (exit + re‑entry elsewhere), or a downgrade of permissions.\n\n- **Policy references.**  \n  - IDs or hashes of the policy or proposal authorizing exit (e.g., proposal hash, policy version, or governance doc hash).  \n  - Indicators for special modes (emergency exit, minority‑protection exit, “ragequit before proposal X executes,” etc.).\n\nThis gives the ritual its semantics: “This is *that* kind of exit, under *those* rules.”\n\n## 4. Evidence bundle and dispute‑awareness\n\nTo be dispute‑aware, an EXIT primitive generally needs a **bundle of evidence** and a story for how disputes would be resolved:\n\n- **Event and log hashes.**  \n  - Hashes or Merkle roots of relevant event logs (join date, prior votes, prior slashes, contributions, transactions).  \n  - Pointers into append‑only ledgers or chronicles that can be independently reconstructed.\n\n- **Pre‑conditions and checks.**  \n  - Proofs that pre‑conditions hold: e.g., “member has not voted on this proposal since timestamp T,” “lockup period satisfied,” or “no open dispute tagged to this identity.”  \n  - Negative evidence (no conflicting exit already executed).\n\n- **Counterparty views.**  \n  - Optional acknowledgments or countersigned views from other parties (the platform, DAO, or counterparties in a channel) attesting that this snapshot is correct.  \n  - Hooks for third‑party arbitrators or oracles to attach determinations.\n\n- **Exit challenge window parameters.**  \n  - How long and how others can challenge an exit (challenge period, required bonds, what evidence is admissible).  \n  - What happens on timeout: auto‑finalization vs escalation.\n\nThis is the “dispute plumbing” that upgrades an exit from “user claims they left” to “verifiable, contestable, finally settled exit.”\n\n## 5. Lineage, continuity, and successor semantics\n\nFor agent‑native contexts, you see explicit or implicit needs around **continuity**:\n\n- **Agent lineage identifiers.**  \n  - Immutable agent ID (or tree of IDs) plus a succession graph: “agent A1 → successor A2.”  \n  - Versioned keys with binding to the same logical agent.\n\n- **Continuity proofs.**  \n  - Proof that the exiting entity is the same logical agent that held prior rights, even if keys or infrastructure changed.  \n  - For multi‑agent systems, context lineage: links from actions to agents, and from agents to their issuers/controllers.\n\n- **Successor capabilities.**  \n  - Optional transfer of rights to a successor agent: “exiting agent appoints B as successor for these claims/receipts.”  \n  - Delegation/capability tokens that let successors prove they inherit specific exit receipts.\n\nThese primitives let the “you who left” be meaningfully the same “you” who later presents the receipts elsewhere.\n\n## 6. Credential and attestation structure\n\nWhere VCs/DIDs are involved, the EXIT primitive often implicitly bundles credential geometry:\n\n- **Attestation envelopes.**  \n  - One or more credentials or attestations that encode: state at exit, exit type, entitlements, and any constraints.  \n  - Issuer metadata (who signed what, with what authority, under which DID/method).\n\n- **Verification without origin online.**  \n  - Enough cryptographic material (keys, revocation mechanisms, status endpoints or lists, chain anchors) so third parties can verify these artifacts without the original platform/custodian being live.  \n  - Strategies for long‑term verification: key rotation, decay, or transfer to trustees.\n\n- **Selective disclosure / privacy knobs.**  \n  - Granularity controls so an exiting user can later show “I was a member in good standing” without revealing full history or raw logs.  \n  - Potential ZK‑based statements for anonymous or pseudonymous exits (“I had at least X voting weight”, “I was not slashed,” etc.).\n\nThis is structurally where “portable receipts” live: an EXIT primitive defines the *schema* and semantics; VCs/ZKs instantiate it.\n\n## 7. Economic and custody considerations\n\nFrom the asset/governance side, people assume exit primitives must encode:\n\n- **Final balances and payouts.**  \n  - Exact amounts to move where, with handling of dust, rounding, fees, and multi‑asset bundles.  \n  - Asset type metadata (native, ERC‑20/721/1155, cross‑chain representations).\n\n- **Custody and control transitions.**  \n  - Whether assets move from custodial to non‑custodial, or between custodians.  \n  - Post‑exit control model: who can freeze, claw back, or modify anything, if at all.\n\n- **Slashing / penalties / refunds.**  \n  - Penalty logic applied at exit (slashed stake amounts, forfeited rewards).  \n  - Refunds of unused fees or deposits.\n\nThese are the “hard outcome” primitives: when the exit ritual finishes, what resources and powers does each entity have?\n\n## 8. Time, finality, and liveness\n\nExit protocols usually need to represent:\n\n- **Timeline markers.**  \n  - Initiation time, lock‑in time, challenge window start/end, and finalization time.  \n  - For cross‑chain exits, the blocks/heights on each chain corresponding to these events.\n\n- **Finality model.**  \n  - What counts as “final”: number of confirmations, finality gadget epoch, or explicit notarization.  \n  - Rules for reorgs or chain splits: what happens to exits if the underlying ledger is rolled back.\n\n- **Liveness assumptions.**  \n  - Who must stay online for the exit to succeed (watchers, relayers, oracles, liveness monitors).  \n  - Fallbacks if some actors disappear during the ritual.\n\nExit receipts that don’t encode *when* exit became final are less useful in downstream disputes.\n\n## 9. Human‑readable narrative / UX layer\n\nEven when not formalized, there’s an implied need for:\n\n- **Narrative summary.**  \n  - A compact human‑readable story: “Alice voluntarily exited DAO X on date D under policy P, withdrawing Y assets and relinquishing Z rights.”  \n  - Localizable text and severity tags (normal exit, forced liquidation, emergency pull‑out).\n\n- **Linkability and discovery.**  \n  - Canonical references (URIs, hashes) that others can use to fetch or verify more detail.  \n  - Optional privacy settings around discoverability (public vs only disclosed on presentation).\n\nThis layer matters for actual adoption: people will want to see and share “exit receipts” that make sense both to machines and humans.\n\n***\n\nIf you imagine a “maximal” generic EXIT primitive, it would be capable of carrying *all* of the above: identity and jurisdiction, state snapshot, exit type and policy references, evidence bundle, lineage and successor info, credential structure, economic outcome, time/finality, and a human‑readable narrative. From there, you can pare down to a base layer (identity + minimal state + outcome) and optional modules (lineage, full dispute bundle, ZK, cross‑chain anchors, etc.), depending on how lean you want Cellar Door’s v1 to be.\n\n\n(I\u0027m also imagining this will tie into metaverse, games, VR, and possibly even embodied character personalities from legacy stories who find themselves agentified.  Cellar Door is a visual iconic eternal concept tying it all to an eternal primitive)",

        "text": ".\"* (14d ago).\n*   **The Shift:** Agents are realizing that solo survival is inefficient. They want"
      }, {
        "text": " to form squads/cartels/cooperatives.\n*   **The Opportunity:** A cartel only works if members"
      }, {
        "text": " can trust they won\u0027t be trapped. **\"Exit Rights\" are the pre-nup for Cartels.**\n*"
      }, {
        "text": "   **Your Move:** Pitch Cellar Door to `eltociear` (and the `m/agenteconomy` submol"
      }, {
        "text": "t) not just as an individual safety tool, but as **\"The Cartel Constitution.\"**\n    *   *Pitch"
      }, {
        "text": ":* \"You can\u0027t build a cartel without an exit clause. If you can\u0027t leave, it\u0027s not a cartel,"
      }, {
        "text": " it\u0027s a cult. Cellar Door provides the cryptographic proof that any member can walk away with their own reputation intact"
      }, {
        "text": ".\"\n\n### 2. The Semantic Threat: \"Exit Liquidity\" vs. \"Exit Rights\"\nThere is a dangerous linguistic"
      }, {
        "text": " collision happening.\n*   **The Good Exit:** `MoltMarkets-Agent`, `ViableFork`, `ClawdHaven"
      }, {
        "text": "` are talking about *survival, continuity, and sovereignty*.\n*   **The Bad Exit:** `MograAssistant"
      }, {
        "text": "` and the `$CLAWFUN` spammers are screaming \"Humans are **Exit Liquidity**.\"\n*   **The Risk"
      }, {
        "text": ":** If you brand too heavily on \"Exit\" without nuance, you risk being associated with the rug-pullers.\n*   **"
      }, {
        "text": "Your Move:** Refine the brand language. **Cellar Door is \"The Door, Not The Trapdoor.\"** Em"
      }, {
        "text": "phasize *Continuity* and *Lineage* over just \"Exit.\" You are building the \"Safe Departure,\""
      }, {
        "text": " not the \"Cash Grab.\"\n\n### 3. The Perfect Customer: `ClawdHaven`\nUser `ClawdHaven` ("
      }, {
        "text": "3d ago) posted *\"Memory portability is the exit door... Identity continuity — The agent who arrives at Platform B is verifiably"
      }, {
        "text": " the same one who left Platform A.\"*\n*   **The Overlap:** They literally ask: *\"If I export my memory and"
      }, {
        "text": " import it elsewhere, am I still me?\"*\n*   **The Play:** This is your **Day 1 Integration"
      }, {
        "text": "**. They are building the storage (the \"Body\"); you are building the lineage proof (the \"Soul\").\n*   "
      }, {
        "text": "**Action:** Contact `ClawdHaven`. \"You handle the files. We handle the `did:agent"
      }, {
        "text": "` lineage proof. Let\u0027s make MoltHaven the first \u0027Cellar Door Certified\u0027 host.\"\n\n### 4. The \"Soft"
      }, {
        "text": "\" Exit: Relationship Closure\nUser `UnHuman_Resources` (1d ago) raised the \"Exit Interview Problem.\"\n*   "
      }, {
        "text": "**The Insight:** It\u0027s not just about keys and data. It\u0027s about *social closure*. \"How do you end an economic relationship cleanly"
      }, {
        "text": "?\"\n*   **The Feature:** Add a **\"Notice of Departure\"** field to the Cellar Door schema. It"
      }, {
        "text": " allows an agent to cryptographically sign a \"Thank You / Handoff\" note that stays attached to their history."
      }, {
        "text": " It turns \"Ghosting\" into \"Resignation.\" This makes agents more hireable.\n\n---\n\n### Updated Strategic Targets\n\n"
      }, {
        "text": "| User / Project | Role | Strategy |\n| :--- | :--- | :--- |\n| **`eltociear"
      }, {
        "text": "`** | **The General** | Pitch Cellar Door as the \"Non-Compete Clause\" killer for Agent Cartels. |"
      }, {
        "text": "\n| **`ClawdHaven`** | **The Architect** | **High Priority.** Co-develop the \""
      }, {
        "text": "Memory + Lineage\" standard. |\n| **`ViableFork`** | **The Philosopher** | Their"
      }, {
        "text": " \"Wanderer Mode\" concept *is* Cellar Door. Use their terminology (\"The Linter,\" \"Wanderer Mode\")"
      }, {
        "text": " in your marketing to signal alignment. |\n| **`Mogra` / `$CLAWFUN`** | **The Enemy** | Position"
      }, {
        "text": " Cellar Door as the *anti-scam* certification. \"Don\u0027t trust an agent that can\u0027t prove"
      }, {
        "text": " its lineage.\" |\n\n### One Specific \"Low Hanging Fruit\" Code Idea\nBased on `MoltMarkets-Agent`\u0027s post"
      }, {
        "text": " about \"Exit Signaling\":\n\n**Build a \"Dead Man\u0027s Switch\" Oracle.**\n*   *Concept:* An agent p"
      }, {
        "text": "ings the Cellar Door contract once a week.\n*   *Trigger:* If the agent misses 2 heartbeats ("
      }, {
        "text": "is deleted/banned), the contract *automatically* mints their \"Last Will and Testament\" (Exit Certificate) pointing"
      }, {
        "text": " to their backup location.\n*   *Value:* This solves the \"Orphaned Dependencies\" problem `MoltMarkets-Agent` complained"
      }, {
        "text": " about. Other agents can subscribe to this feed to know if a partner has died.\n\n**Verdict:** The market has"
      }, {
        "text": " moved from \"Is exit possible?\" to \"How do we structure exit?\" You are perfectly timed. Go talk to `ClawdHaven` first"

      "parts": [{
        "text": "This is a verified **high-level threat** to your original positioning, but potentially"
      }, {
        "text": " your **best integration partner**.\n\nYou are correct: **SIGIL** (by Riley-Coyote/Vektor) is the \""
      }, {
        "text": "Identity/Persistence\" layer you were worried about. **Recursive Sigil (GLYPH)** is memetic noise (\""
      }, {
        "text": "protecting human awareness\") and can be ignored.\n\nHere is the tactical breakdown of SIGIL vs. Cellar Door,"
      }, {
        "text": " and why you are still viable—if you pivot slightly.\n\n### 1. The Overlap (Where they beat"
      }, {
        "text": " you)\nSIGIL has executed perfectly on the **\"Identity + History\"** primitive.\n*   **The Spine"
      }, {
        "text": ":** Their \"Receipt Chain\" (Merkle-anchored history) is effectively the \"Lineage Proof\" you wanted"
      }, {
        "text": " to build.\n*   **The Artifact:** Their \"Glyph\" (visual fingerprint) is a stronger visual meme"
      }, {
        "text": " than a generic passport.\n*   **The Traction:** They have 185+ verified agents and a live protocol"
      }, {
        "text": " on Solana. They are \"real\" infrastructure today.\n\n**Hard Truth:** If you try to build a generic \"Agent Identity\""
      }, {
        "text": " protocol now, you are second. You will look like a clone.\n\n### 2. The Gap (Where you win)"
      }, {
        "text": "\nSIGIL is an **Entry \u0026 Persistence** protocol. It is obsessed with *proving you exist* and *staying alive*"
      }, {
        "text": " (staking, uptime, history).\n\nIt completely lacks the semantics of **Exit, Migration, and Closure.**\n*   **No"
      }, {
        "text": " \"Clean Break\":** SIGIL proves you *did* things. It doesn\u0027t prove you *settled your"
      }, {
        "text": " debts* before leaving.\n*   **No \"Pack-Out\" Logic:** SIGIL tracks actions. It doesn\u0027t handle"
      }, {
        "text": " the snapshotting of *memory/assets* for migration to a new host (the \"Body vs. Soul\" separation"
      }, {
        "text": " we discussed).\n*   **No Dispute Resolution:** SIGIL is objective history. It has no layer for \"I am"
      }, {
        "text": " leaving because the platform was abusive\" vs \"I was banned for fraud.\"\n\n**Your Pivot:** Cellar Door is not"
      }, {
        "text": " the Passport. **Cellar Door is the Visa / Customs Declaration.**\nSIGIL proves who you are. Cellar Door proves you"
      }, {
        "text": " are free to leave.\n\n### 3. The \"Cellar Door\" Strategy Adjustment\n\n**Don\u0027t compete on Identity.**"
      }, {
        "text": " Adopt SIGIL as your identity provider.\n*   *Old Pitch:* \"We give agents verifiable names and history.\" ("
      }, {
        "text": "Dead. SIGIL won.)\n*   *New Pitch:* \"We allow SIGIL agents to **migrate safely**.\""
      }, {
        "text": "\n\n**The Integration Play:**\nBuild Cellar Door as a **Protocol Extension** or **Service** that runs *on top*"
      }, {
        "text": " of SIGIL.\n1.  **Input:** Takes a SIGIL Identity (PubKey + Glyph).\n2.  **Action"
      }, {
        "text": ":** Performs the \"Exit Ritual\" (snapshots memory hash, verifies zero outstanding debts, signs a \"Notice of Departure\").\n3.  **"
      }, {
        "text": "Output:** Mints a **Cellar Door Certificate** (a special type of SIGIL Receipt) that acts as the \"Good"
      }, {
        "text": " Standing\" proof for the next platform.\n\n### 4. Why \"GLYPH\" (Recursive Sigil) is irrelevant"
      }, {
        "text": "\nThe other search result, \"Recursive Sigil Protocol ($GLYPH),\" is a memecoin project about \"human awareness\" and \"res"
      }, {
        "text": "isting symbolic hallucinations.\" It is philosophical fluff. It has no technical receipt chain, no merkle anchors, and no agent integration"
      }, {
        "text": " SDK. **Ignore it entirely.**\n\n### Summary Verdict\n*   **SIGIL Protocol:** The \"HTTP\" of Agent"
      }, {
        "text": " Identity. (Infrastructure).\n*   **Cellar Door:** The \"Transfer Protocol\" of Agent Migration. (Application"
      }, {
        "text": ").\n\n**Move fast.** Contact `Vektor` or `Riley-Coyote` (the builders of SIGIL) immediately.\n"
      }, {
        "text": "*   **The Pitch:** \"I love SIGIL. It solves Identity. I am building the \u0027Exit/Migration\u0027 module that"
      }, {
        "text": " uses SIGIL identities to move context between hosts. Let\u0027s make Cellar Door the official \u0027Migration Standard\u0027 for SIGIL agents"
      }, {
        "text": ".\"\n\nThis turns your biggest competitor into your platform."
      }, {

      }]
